context: All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will appear in the company today. Everyone who has lunch in the company schedules meetings with their customers. Employees will either have lunch in the company or have lunch at home. If an employee has lunch at home, then he/she is working remotely from home. All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home. No managers work remotely from home. James is either a manager and appears in the company today or neither a manager nor appears in the company today.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? James has lunch in the company.
raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:
Employee(x) ::: x is an employee.
Schedule(x, y) ::: x schedules a meeting with y.
Appear(x, y) ::: x appears in y.
Lunch(x) ::: x has lunch.
Home(x) ::: x has lunch at home.
Work(x) ::: x works remotely from home.
Manager(x) ::: x is a manager.
Premises:
∀x (Employee(x) → Schedule(x, y)) ::: All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will appear in the company today.
∀x (Lunch(x) → Schedule(x, y)) ::: Everyone who has lunch in the company schedules meetings with their customers.
∀x (Lunch(x) → Home(x)) ::: Employees will either have lunch in the company or have lunch at home.
∀x (Lunch(x) → Work(x)) ::: If an employee has lunch at home, then he/she is working remotely from home.
∀x (Lunch(x) → ¬Work(x)) ::: All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home.
¬Manager(james) → (Manager(james) ∧ Appearance(james, today)) ::: No managers work remotely from home.
Conclusion:
Lunch(james) ::: James has lunch in the company.
------

Michael can block any shooting from a person as long as the person does not jump when shooting. Michael cannot block Windy's shooting. Every shooter who can jump when shooting is a great shooter.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Peter can block Windy's shooting.
raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:
Taller(x, y) ::: x is taller than y.
Block(x, y) ::: x can block y.
Jump(x) ::: x jumps when shooting.
Great(x) ::: x is a great shooter.
Premises:
∀x (Taller(x, y) → Block(x, y)) ::: If a man is taller than another man, the taller one can block the other's shooting.
Taller(michael, everyone) ::: Michael is a man who is taller than everyone else in his class.
∀x (Taller(x, y) ∧ Taller(y, z) → Taller(x, z)) ::: If person x is taller than person y, and person y is taller than person z, than x is taller than z.
Taller(peter, michael) ::: Peter is a man who is taller than Michael.
Block(peter, windy) ::: Windy is a man who is taller than Peter.
Jump(peter) ::: Peter can jump when shooting.
Great(peter) ::: Peter is a great shooter.
Conclusion:
Block(peter, windy) ::: Peter can block Windy's shooting.
------

context: If something can transport multiple passengers, then they are not empty. All airlines can transport multiple passengers. All planes are empty. All Boeing 707s are planes. If Greyhound is not an airline, then there are no Greyhound planes.
question: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Greyhound is an airline.
raw_logic_programs:
Predicates:
CanTransport(x, y) ::: x can transport y.
Empty(x) ::: x is empty.
Airplane(x) ::: x is an airplane.
Boeing707(x) ::: x is a Boeing 707.
Greyhound(x) ::: x is Greyhound.
Premises:
∀x (CanTransport(x, y) → ¬Empty(x)) ::: If something can transport multiple passengers, then they are not empty.
∀x (Airplane(x) → Empty(x)) ::: All airlines can transport multiple passengers.
∀x (Plane(x) → Empty(x)) ::: All planes are empty.
∀x (Boeing707(x) → Plane(x)) ::: All Boeing 707s are planes.
¬(Airplane(boeing707) ∧ Greyhound) → ¬(Airplane(boeing707) ∧ Plane(boeing707)) ::: If Greyhound is not an airline, then there are no Greyhound planes.
Conclusion:
Airplane(boeing707) ::: Greyhound is an airline.
------

Monkey(x) ::: Rock is a monkey.

Conclusion:
WellAttended(john) ::: John has a wedding that is well-attended.
